author: J.A. Gómez
title: El temporal de lluvia en España no da tregua: llega una nueva borrasca con hasta 150 l/m2 y rachas de viento de 100 km/h
text:
Las lluvias serán abundantes hasta el viernes por la dana y durante el fin de semana por la llegada de una nueva borrasca, que dejará acumulados de hasta 150 litros por metro cuadrado (l/m2) en zonas favorables de la vertiente atlántica. Además, las rachas de viento podrían superar los 60 a 70 kilómetros por hora (km/h) en muchas áreas, y de forma más local, es probable que alcancen o superen los 100 km/h.
Los expertos de el portal meteorológico Eltiempo.es han explicado que la dana seguirá marcando el tiempo en España hasta este jueves. De esta manera, lloverá en casi todo el territorio peninsular , aunque cuanto más al norte esté uno, menos probabilidades tendrá de lidiar con las lluvias, que serán en líneas generales menos intensas. De hecho, en la cornisa cantábrica apenas habrá lluvia.
Por el contrario, habrá lluvias abundantes en zonas del este del país, donde hay avisos naranjas activos en Almería, Valencia, Castellón y Tarragona. En estas dos jornadas, los acumulados de precipitación podrían superar los 200 a 300 l/m2 de forma local. Asimismo, las precipitaciones también van a ser destacables en zonas del sur de Andalucía, Extremadura y cara sur del Sistema Central .
Salas EFE
Las reservas en los embalses en España suben un 57% en sólo un año: "No quiere decir que la situación sea buena" La nueva borrasca comenzará su desarrollo durante la madrugada del viernes y se profundizará rápidamente hasta alcanzar una presión mínima por debajo de 985 hectopascales (hPa). Los meteorólogos han destacado la relevancia que también tendrán las posibles zonas de baja presión secundarias que se formarían y disiparían alrededor de la borrasca principal, ya que podrían incrementar las precipitaciones.
Así, el portal meteorológico ha explicado que el viernes será de nuevo otra jornada lluviosa . En este marco, se registrarán chubascos de madrugada, especialmente en el este del país, que podrían ser localmente intensos, y ganarán en extensión a medida que avance la jornada. A mediodía, es probable que esté lloviendo otra vez en casi todo el territorio peninsular.
El primer frente frío asociado a la borrasca llegará al oeste peninsular por la tarde. A su paso, dejará lluvias abundantes y persistentes en zonas del oeste de Andalucía y Extremadura. Además, Eltiempo.es ha explicado que se formaría en el interior del país una línea de chubascos, lo que dejará importantes acumulados de lluvia. No se descartan tormentas en esta zona.
La borrasca 'Jana' Con la llegada de la nueva borrasca, el portal meteorológico ha avisado que habrá rachas podrían superar los 60 a 70 km/h en muchas áreas. De forma más local, es probable que alcancen o superen los 100 km/h. Probablemente, esto conllevará la activación de diversos avisos con viento, por lo que se prevé que la borrasca sea nombrada como Jana.
Un segundo frente frío asociado a una borrasca secundaria avanzaría desde el oeste durante la madrugada del sábado. Tal y como ha detallado el portal meteorológico, reforzaría las lluvias de forma notable en todo el oeste y, a mediodía, alcanzaría el interior peninsular. Por la tarde, afectaría al este y a los Pirineos.
Después de ello, avanzarían nuevas líneas de inestabilidad desde el oeste, que barrerían el país y dejarían nuevas precipitaciones. De esta manera, los chubascos y tormentas serán extensos e intensos durante el domingo, sobre todo en el oeste, sur y centro de la España peninsular. Con todo ello, los expertos han detallado que los acumulados de lluvia podrían superar los 50 l/m2 durante el fin de semana en gran parte de la vertiente atlántica. En zonas favorables, esta cifra podría superar los 100 l/m2 e incluso los 150 l/m2.
Además de la lluvia y el viento, el portal meteorológico ha avisado que la borrasca estará asociada a un descenso térmico, lo que también hará que la cota de nieve baje. Por encima de los 1.500 metros, el acumulado de nieve nueva podría superar el medio metro en los sistemas Béticos, sistema Central y Pirineos. De forma local, en cotas altas, podrían superarse el metro o metro y medio en zonas del Gredos y Pirineos. Asimismo, durante la madrugada del domingo la cota podría descender hasta los 1000 m en zonas del interior y norte del país.
NEWSLETTER - CIENCIA Salud, nutrición y avances científicos en tu correo todos los sábados Apuntarme De conformidad con el RGPD y la LOPDGDD, EL LEÓN DE EL ESPAÑOL PUBLICACIONES, S.A. tratará los datos facilitados con la finalidad de remitirle noticias de actualidad.

author: @sophiapatelweb3
title: Guizhou Official's Alleged Bitcoin Mining Denied by Authorities
text:
Key Points: Authorities deny Jing Yaping’s involvement in Bitcoin mining. No recorded impact on cryptocurrencies reported. Official dismissed allegations as AI-generated rumor. The Guizhou Provincial Commission for Discipline Inspection debunked claims that former Big Data Bureau director Jing Yaping mined 327 Bitcoins, confirming the case did not involve cryptocurrency.
This clarification averts potential misinformation impacts on the cryptocurrency market, underscoring the importance of verifying reports from credible, official sources.
Authorities Refute AI-Generated Bitcoin Mining Allegations Allegations surfaced claiming that Jing Yaping, former director of Guizhou’s Big Data Bureau, used government resources to mine Bitcoins. The commission for discipline inspection denies these claims, stating her case was unrelated to cryptocurrency. These accusations originated from unverified online sources, later identified as AI-generated content.
The Chinese authorities’ response, denying any mining activities, underscores the state’s strong stance against misinformation and improper use of government resources. As a staff member from the Publicity Department of the Guizhou Provincial Commission for Discipline Inspection and Supervision confirmed, “the news that Jing Yaping used a government server to mine 327 bitcoins was ‘a rumor.’ According to their understanding, Jing Yaping’s case did not involve bitcoin.”
Key figures in the crypto industry, such as major exchange CEOs and regulation experts, have yet to comment publicly on this case. Official dismissal of the rumors stresses the importance of verifying sources in news, especially related to crypto assets.
Misinformation in Crypto: A Call for Vigilance Did you know? Reports of officials engaging in unauthorized crypto mining have arisen before, yet China’s crackdown remains steadfast with no similar precedent matching Jing Yaping’s alleged scale.
Bitcoin (BTC) is currently valued at $123,141.18, as reported by CoinMarketCap . The trading volume over the last 24 hours reached $96.12 billion, reflecting a 28.03% increase. Bitcoin’s price has risen by 3.14% in the past 24 hours, maintaining a dominant market share of 58.61%.
Bitcoin(BTC), daily chart, screenshot on CoinMarketCap at 04:56 UTC on August 14, 2025. Source: CoinMarketCap Insights from the Coincu research team emphasize how incidents like these serve as reminders of the need for regulatory vigilance. The spread of misinformation in crypto is a challenge both for authorities and investors aiming to maintain a stable market environment. For related provincial registration information, see Guangdong Province Registration Information .
DISCLAIMER : The information on this website is provided as general market commentary and does not constitute investment advice. We encourage you to do your own research before investing. Rate this post

author: Harvey Barbee
title: Fresno, CA – One Injured in Crash on Hwy 41 near Herndon Ave
text:
Fresno, CA (December 19, 2024) – Emergency crews responded to a car accident on Highway 41 near Herndon Ave in Fresno on Wednesday evening. The crash, reported at approximately 5:37 p.m., resulted in injuries and prompted an immediate response from local authorities.
According to the California Highway Patrol, at least one individual sustained injuries in the collision and was transported to a nearby hospital for medical treatment. While specific details about the vehicles involved have not been disclosed, officials confirmed that emergency responders provided care at the scene. Traffic delays were reported in the area as authorities worked to secure the site and begin an investigation into the cause of the accident.
The circumstances surrounding the collision remain under investigation, and additional information may be released as it becomes available. Our thoughts are with the injured victim, and we hope for a swift recovery.
Car Accidents on California Highways California highways, including Highway 41 in Fresno, are often the site of traffic accidents due to the high volume of vehicles and challenging road conditions. Collisions in these areas are frequently caused by distracted driving, speeding, or abrupt lane changes. Intersections near major thoroughfares like Herndon Ave are particularly vulnerable to accidents due to merging traffic and high speeds.
The California Highway Patrol reports thousands of accidents annually on state highways, many resulting in injuries. Public safety campaigns and enforcement efforts aim to reduce these incidents, but accidents remain a persistent issue for drivers in the region.
In the aftermath of a collision, individuals are advised to seek medical attention, document the incident thoroughly, and report the crash to the authorities. These steps are essential for protecting legal rights and facilitating resolution in insurance or legal matters.
For more information or to receive help after an accident, contact Local Accident Reports.

author: Paul Homewood
title: The climate scaremongers: BBC suppresses good news on India’s monsoons
text:
INDIA’S monsoon season, which runs from June to September, has again been wetter than average, which is excellent news for the country. Plentiful rain is, of course, of vital importance to agriculture. It also fills the dams used for hydro power and gives the whole economy a boost.
https://mausam.imd.gov.in/imd_latest/contents/rainfall_time_series.php
Reuters reports: ‘India’s monsoon rainfall this year was its highest since 2020. India’s annual monsoon provides almost 70 per cent of the rain it needs to water farms and replenish reservoirs and aquifers, and is the lifeblood of a nearly $3.5trillion economy. Without irrigation, nearly half of Indian farmland depends on the rains that usually run from June to September.’ https://uk.finance.yahoo.com/news/indias-monsoon-rains-hit-four-121413615.html
The last drought was in 2015. By far the worst series of droughts occurred between 1960 and 1990, and these were a direct consequence of global cooling at the time, something which climate scientists in those days knew well.
In contrast, global warming between the 1920s and 40s brought plentiful rain for India.
https://mol.tropmet.res.in/monsoon-interannual-timeseries/
These facts may come as a surprise to anybody who watches the BBC. Not only have they failed, as far as I can see, to report this good news, they even had the temerity two years ago to report that India’s monsoons were drying up! But good climate news does not suit their agenda.
https://www.bbc.com/future/article/20220517-the-uncertain-fate-of-asias-monsoons
The reason for the catastrophic floods in North Carolina
https://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/images/153387/devastating-rainfall-from-hurricane-helene
LAST week I wrote about the impact of Hurricane Helene on Florida. https://www.conservativewoman.co.uk/the-climate-scaremongers-hurricane-helene-was-bad-but-nowhere-near-the-worst/ As I mentioned, there was also considerable flooding inland, particularly in North Carolina.
The US National Weather Service (NWS) have now published full data on the floods there, and it is important that we understand their message.
The rainfall from Helene, which by the time it got inland had degraded to a tropical storm, largely impacted the western part of the state around the town of Asheville, which lies amongst the Blue Ridge mountains. According to NWS, Asheville itself received 13.98 inches over three days, and over the higher ground totals of more than 20 inches were recorded in a few places.
Such rainfall totals seem incredible to people living in Britain, but are not uncommon where tropical storms are concerned. Hurricane Floyd, for example, dropped 19 inches on Wilmington, NC in 1999, before proceeding to break rainfall records in South Carolina, Virginia, Maryland, Delaware, Pennsylvania and New York.
Floyd hit the low-lying eastern half of North Carolina. Helene in contrast hit the mountainous area, which meant that water quickly cascaded into the river valleys, exacerbating the flooding. But the biggest factor with Helene was that the storm was trapped over Asheville for three days because of atmospheric blocking. Rainfall there amounted to about four or five inches each day, which as we have seen is not exceptional in itself; cumulatively however it was.
The flooding around Asheville was not unprecedented either. In July 1916, even more devastating flooding hit exactly the same part of the state, after 22 inches fell in 24 hours, which is still a record for the whole of the US, following a hurricane which had made landfall at Charleston.
I would thoroughly recommend looking at the historical account of this disaster, which can be read here. It begins: ‘The flood of 1916 broke every record in the book. The death and destruction it caused in Western North Carolina defined flooding for an entire generation of survivors, and their stories live on nearly 100 years later. ‘
The photos alone tell the story.
Unsurprisingly many in the media have jumped at the chance to blame the severity of the floods on global warming. But this is not supported by the facts. It was not the intensity of the rain which caused so much devastation, but the fact that the storm was stuck there for three days instead of quickly moving away.
